Java - Anonymous Inner Class

Created:2018-03-10  Last modified:2018-03-10

  • Introduction
  • Examples

  1. Introduction

    Anonymous class is a class that does not have name, which means it can only be initialized once.

    It must be defined based on a Parent class or an interface. It will use the parent's constructor.

    Anonymous class is actually a class's subclass.

  2. Examples

    1. Create from interface

      public class Anonymous {
    public static void main(String [] args){
        Show A = new Show() {
            @Override
            public void show() {
                System.out.println("Anonymous");
            }
        };
        A.show();
    }
}
interface Show{
    public void show();
}

    2. Inherit parent's constructor

      public class Anonymous2 {
    public static void main(String [] args){
        // This is not to new a Show2 class, but to create a subclass and instantiate it.
        Show2 s = new Show2(){
            // a constructor without name without argument
            {
                System.out.println("new constructor");
            }
          @Override
          public void print(){
              System.out.println("Sub print");
          }
        };
        s.print();

    }
}

class Show2{
    public Show2(){
        System.out.println("Show Default Constructor");
    }
    public void print(){
        System.out.println("Show default print");
    }
}

    3. Variable scope

      If the anonymous class's object is used as a class member, it can access all (including private) outer class member variables and functions

      If the anonymous class's object is used as a function member, it can access final local varaible of the function.

      public class Anonymous3 {
    private String name;
    private Show3 s3;
    private void fun(){
        System.out.println("name: " + name);
    }
    private Anonymous3(){
        name = "Anonymous3";
        // it can access the outer class member
        s3 = new Show3() {
            @Override
            public void print() {
                fun();
            }
        };
    }
    public static void main(String [] args){
        Anonymous3 a3 = new Anonymous3();
        a3.s3.print();

    }
}
abstract class Show3{
    public abstract void print();
}

      Final modifier

      public class anonymous4 {
    public static void main(String [] args){
        final int num = 10;
        Show4 s = new Show4(){
          @Override
          public void print(){
              System.out.println(num);
          }
        };
        s.print();
        // num++;
    }
}

class Show4{
    public void print(){}
}
